subject: RE: [junit] Testing certain types of methods
msgSnippet: limitation != bad Are you asking how that limitation can be a bad thing?  That s a whole other question.  ;-) Todd. ________________________________ From:
messageBody:
limitation != bad

Are you asking how that limitation can be a bad thing? That's a whole
other question. ;-)


Todd.


________________________________

From: Soaring Eagle [mailto:comfortable.numb@...]
Sent: Monday, February 14, 2005 2:51 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Testing certain types of methods


repeat: how can *that* be a limitation? Do you mean that
sometimes it
is not commercially desirable to improvde design and at such
times,
JUnit's inability to be flexible is a limitation?

By the way, at times, i do use Junit to functional black box
testing.
Such use of Junit makes it a glorified stand alone Java client -
but
what the heck.


On Mon, 14 Feb 2005 14:08:36 -0700, Bradley, Todd
<todd.bradley@...> wrote:
> It limits you from sticking with your poor design.
>
>
>
> ________________________________
>
> From: Soaring Eagle [mailto:comfortable.numb@...]
> Sent: Monday, February 14, 2005 1:57 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Testing certain types of methods
>
>
>
> how can this be a limitation?
>
>
> On Mon, 14 Feb 2005 15:37:04 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger
> <jbrains@...> wrote:
> > Vamsee Kanakala wrote:
> >
> > > Absolutely! And I'm amazed at how many design
mistakes I
> find while
> > > unit-testing. You're trying to test something, it
feels
> unintuitive, and
> > > ka-boom! You know what's wrong. JUnit rocks!
> >
> > For every one of you, there are a hundred others who
see this
> as a
> > limitation of JUnit. Shame.
> > --
> > J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
